These characters, and Lucy, you can upgrade by getting soul stones and spending them in the tab menu (leveling up stats and drafting another card for that character). From here you basically have a map with events similar to other deck builders but, where this one stands apart, you can do everything as long as you can pay the cost (usually through keys, health, or money). There are 3 core areas with a few others that unlock later in the story. As you succeed or fail runs the world grows and the story, presented through skip-able VN-style dialogue, continues (not a big deal; you can continue to play after completing the story) and you're sent back to the over-world.

Finally the developers put quite a bit into the game and it shows. All of the characters feel unique but are pretty well balanced. As others have said, this is an excellent card game. You get a basic tutorial in the very beginning, but there are a lot of subtle mechanics that it will take a while to get used to. More important than the mechanics of the game is understanding how to synergize your cards with one another. Certain characters work really well together, and getting cards that work well is key to winning. You can win without the above if you know what you're doing, but it becomes a lot easier if you synergize.

To be clear, I'm not a master of the game yet. I got to The Reaper and he destroyed me...and then again, and again...I beat him on my fifth try. I was kind of disappointed because it seemed the game was too short. And then I unlocked a new area, so I ran the game again. I beat The Reaper again, though I felt weaker this time (the characters I used don't work well together)...and then I met big daddy. He bent me over like a red-headed step-child and, well...I'll spare you the details. Long and short of it I'm still not done done with the game (it seems like you beat the game after your first Reaper win, but not really).

The basic mechanics of the game go like this: You pick two investigators of your choice (there are 20 total, though you will only have something like 6 to start). Investigators have 3 types: tank, attack, support. Support=healing and other buffs, attack=attack (obviously), and tank=other random abilities/support/debuff, etc.). At first I thought 2 attack, one support, and one tank was good, but I absolutely destroyed The Reaper with 2 healers (Pressel/Joey), a tank (Ironheart), and an attack (Azar) so I would just say get at least one of each and go from there.

You will then wander around a hexagonal area in your first zone and fight enemies. There are about 4-7~ fights per area including the boss (more as you go on). After defeating an enemy you get soulstones. These are used to upgrade your skills (more mana, draw skills, or level up your heroes, and a few other misc uses in the areas). There are equippable items you will discover, relics (powerful items to help you on your run, but you can only use four), potions, scrolls, skill books, and more.

Your first bonfire (area between areas) will let you pick another investigator out of 3 choices. Then two more after that you get to pick your final investigator. The fifth area is where you fight The Reaper, so you get some time each run to familiarize yourself before you get destroyed by him.

There are 2 game modes--normal (die and restart, losing all party progression) or hope (keep your level ups, etc. and start again). I really think normal is the best way to play, as it's hard but fair once you know what you're doing.

There isn't a ton of stuff for perma progression--you will net 10 credits if you defeat all the bosses up to The Reaper. You can unlock new equipment, friendship items (you can gift to the investigators to become friends and have more card choices per level up), and skills.

As far as the characters, they all have unique personalities, cards, and fighting styles. I'm still learning the ones I have and I have to unlock 8 characters still.

I really enjoy this game, it's wonderful. I highly recommend.

10/10.

Aight, This game has been one of my favorite EA/Indie releases, and Ill try and keep it brief in terms of features/mechanics:

This is a Roguelite, Deckbuilder JRPG with [up-to] a 4-man Party.
What I fully believe sets this differently to JRPGs in general is how bosses and character mechanics absolutely use the fact that they are CARDS.

Most bosses have a mechanic directly tied to this. Be it checking targets with the current hand, checking for specific cards in hand, or tagging cards in hand with a buff/debuff.

It also, fairly uniquely does have another mechanic called "Healing Gauge", which basically pressures you into healing damage as soon as it's taken [the most recent instance of damage is converted to healing gauge, healing is 100% effective on this gauge, and is reduced NOTICEABLY if you attempt to heal past it].

Of course, aside that, you DO have a Slay the spire-ish mana-per turn and card mana cost to go with this along with more "standard" JRPG dealings like Taunt status, Role Trinity [in party composition], and equipment/relics that can change and/or make the run a success.

Runs at the start, might take ~3 hours to finish while you're unsure how a character works or dealing with the unknown boss mechanics, however with enough familiarity this should be reducing to ~1:30 hrs ish, even less if fully dedicated tbh.

I love roguelikes. I've played through a ton of them, such as Inscryption, One Step From Eden, FTL, Dead Cells, Enter the Gungeon, Slay the Spire, Hades, Plate Up!, NecroDancer, and the Binding of Isaac.

All of those games are good, but I like Chrono Ark more than any of them. Bar none it is my favorite Roguelike I've ever played, my favorite new game of 2023, and one of my favorite games of all time. And it's still in Early Access!

Here is how I like each part of the game in depth-

GAMEPLAY
The gameplay for this game is very fun. You control a party of 4 characters, and build a team out of different artifacts and equipment to defeat enemies. Each character is unique in their own right, and it's really cool to build your team around their strengths and to see how they interact. There are 20 characters to play as, and many of them are fun. 

The bosses of this game are also very good. They are very creative to the deck-building roguelike formula in general. They are meant to exploit weaknesses, and it's cool to adjust your playstyle thinking about the bosses you will randomly fight. There are over a dozen bosses to fight, so every run feels very unique.

The game's combat is also very in-depth and has a lot of layers. I've played for 42 hours and I am still learning new things to optimize my game better. There are many advanced mechanics as you unlock the harder modes and it's cool to learn how things work. It makes this game fun for beginners (if not a bit of a learning curve), and great for experts as well. 

Gameplay is 9.5/10. Only complaint is the learning curve and the brutal difficulty if you are going for the hard stuff, but you get what you sign up for.

CHARACTERS AND STORY
The story is very good in this game. It has a lot of layers. The true ending (so far) really made me think a lot, and it was overall really cool. The story isn't always in your face either. It kind of lets you explore how much you care about the story and the characters, which I really like in video games. I do wish there was a bit better of a skipping option through cutscenes you've already seen, however. The story is a bit edgy as well, but it is also very well thought out.

The characters are also very good. The art is polished and nice and there are a lot of little interactions that you can have with the people you recruit, which is a nice little touch. Some characters are a bit one-dimensional, but they gain depth if you view the optional stuff.

Overall, the story and characters is great, one of the best for a roguelike. Only roguelike I can think that rivals this in story and characters is Hades.

PRESENTATION
I really like the worldbuilding in this game. Each level feels like it has its own personality and are really creative. You've got a cursed rose garden, a creepy abandoned amusement park, and a snow-covered graveyard, among some others. Each feel very unique and stand out. The deeper worldbuilding is cool too.

The music is also excellent, and I wish that it was on spotify. I especially love both the Level 2 Boss themes and the Level 3 field, battle, and boss music. Also the final boss themes go hard.

There is a level of jank to this game, however, with it being in early access. There are a lot of things that don't seem to work as intended, a lot of text seems to not be translated, and sometimes there is a bit of load time when entering a cutscene.


TL;DR, this game is fantastic. Worth every penny. My favorite roguelike I've ever played.
9.5/10.

Great game that gets a lot of things right about the genre, whose gameplay also feels very unique by comparison.

Chrono Ark strikes a very impressive balance between the resource management and sequencing common in deckbuilders and the team-building of a turn-based dungeon crawler. There's enough drafting and impactful enough relics to feel a strong sense of variance between runs, while each character's card pool is consistent enough that they can be relied upon to do the jobs you chose them for.

Something this game also gets right is enemy design: sequencing your turns in combat requires a lot of attention and familiarity with the combat mechanics & individual enemy behaviors. The bosses in particular put a lot of pressure on you, but I've generally found them to be very creative and flavorful, with some very well thought-out counterplay mechanics: often the order and composition of your hand determines who the boss targets, and it feels like all of the tools the game gives you to answer certain situations have really rewarding use-cases when you plan for each encounter.

Each character also functions very differently, with each character in a given role providing overlapping utility in a way that feels nothing like their neighbors. Just changing one unit on your team for another character in the role can feel like you're playing a completely different game, and there really is something for every preferred play-style here. This in particular is what keeps me coming back to the game; somehow, I never feel like I fully grasp all the ways to use a character, then it all feels fresh again when I start messing around with someone else.

Aside from the gameplay, which I wholeheartedly recommend to anyone who enjoys deckbuilders and/or dungeon crawlers, there's a lot more to love here. Other than character and relic unlocks which are for the most part pretty quick to do, there's not really any metaprogression: a character has access to their whole kit upon unlocking them, so the game feels well balanced on a run-to-run basis. The story behind the game has a lot of surprising and entertaining twists. And the presentation of the game especially deserves a mention: almost every card has a unique animation with really snappy and satisfying sound design without ever feeling time-consuming to watch. The soundtrack often transitions between a map theme and battle theme seamlessly per area, and there are some absolute banger boss tracks.

I've written this review when the game feels near completion, and I'm extremely excited for its full release. It's a challenging, but very rewarding game with a ton of replay value on account of really intelligent design. Every part of the game just works really well for me. The English translation and clarity of combat mechanics and certain card functionality could use another pass, is really the only caveat I have about the game. It's really good, play it.

Chrono Ark is a combination turn-based RPG and roguelike deckbuilder. Each time you throw yourself into the dungeons, you start a new build from level 1 and a deck of bottom-tier starter cards. Craft your deck, level up and grow your party, and collect the Time Shades needed to save the world. But there's more going on underneath the surface. Across runs, you'll uncover conspiracies, and it becomes clear that you need to find a way to go off script...

Deck building is pretty unique in this game. Each run, you start with two party members and gradually increase to four. Each character has their own card pool, which is small enough that you'll see all of their non-rare cards in a single playthrough with them. So the deck building can feel limiting. But that's because you have a small monkey brain: between all of the characters in the game, there are about as many cards as in a more traditional deckbuilder like Slay the Spire or Monster Train. What it really means is that you have an incredible amount of control over which cards you are offered. Over runs, you'll learn how each character performs, and then you'll start to figure out synergies between them. If you have a weak build, it's definitely on you, not because you got bad luck with card offerings.

The bosses and late-game mooks are huge standouts. Each one brings a unique game mechanic or three with it. They're not just damage sponges - they're whole-ass puzzles! Read the buffs and debuffs that appear very carefully, and see if you can piece together just exactly how the boss is trying to screw you over. One boss changes who it targets based on which cards you play - but all of your plays are forced into a queue instead of taking effect immediately, so you have to mentally keep track of where aggro moves. Another boss adds a card to your hand each turn that forces you to put nasty debuffs on your own party, and neglecting to do so means the entire party gets punished. Yet another requires you to play your own attacks against your own party, then ups the ante by possessing your characters until you can snap them out of it by smacking them around. Every single boss has something this deep and unique going for it.

The real standout for me, though, is the story. This ain't your typical four to six very best friends band together to keep magic Hitler from becoming God. The story, as it's initially presented to you, is that mankind is trapped on a floating island after the world was destroyed by a corrupting miasma, and now you must travel into what's left to collect the magic to turn back time. But this is a blatant lie. The truth is far more complicated, the stakes are unimaginably high, and you are being played like a fiddle by the puppet masters. But the villains aren't evil gods or sorcerers who need to be killed. They're ordinary people who mean well. It's simply that things have gotten so far out of control that they had to make some difficult decisions, and now they're in so deep that it's not possible to back off.

That doesn't make them one iota less dangerous.

[h2] An Engaging Card Game with An RPG Gimmick [/h2]

As a hybrid RPG/Roguelike card game, Chrono Ark delivers a fresh experience for those drawn to the card game aspect but may leave RPG fans wanting.

- Party, Countdowns and Overload mechanics encourage creativity with deck construction.
- Good variety of bosses and boss mechanics.

- Story mostly delivered via supplemental archives instead of being woven into the main play experience.

[h3] Recommend To: [/h3]
- Fans of roguelike card games that need something more than just mechanics for their next fix.
- Anime fans, particularly fans of science fantasy animes like Steins;Gate or 13 Sentinels.
- Anyone who takes Final Fantasy music into their car, the park or the gym.

[h3] You Might Instead Enjoy: [/h3]
- [b] Griftlands [/b] - A roguelike card game dripping with personality. Sharp writing, strong atmosphere and plenty of mechanical depth, but a game with small, shallow character vignettes instead of a single driving narrative.

I love getting immersed in the dreary atmosphere of the Twisted Land. There is something about the sound design that just really works here - it completely sells this "hopeless world, fighting to survive" aspect. And it has the difficulty to really live up to that.

Now of course at this point, after 140+ hours of playing, I can pretty reliably reach the final boss even on Expert (Hard) mode, but that certainly wasn't always the case, in fact I died on the very first major boss on my first run (as have many, I'd assume) because the combat mechanics are not entirely obvious at first. 

Now with any Roguelike, the amount of RNG that goes into a run is always a balancing act between the player having almost no agency in what happens and each run being too easily streamlined leading to repetitiveness . I would say that this game treads this line fairly well, with a skilled player maybe eding towards the latter a bit. There is a certain weight in play to favor you, such as recruitable team members most often consisting of the roles (DPS, Tank or Healer) you don't currently have in your team.

Speaking of roles, I think they did a great job in making each role feel impactful and valuable and forcing the player to not just completely neglect either Damage or Defense/Sustain. At a base level, there is a DPS check in every fight because the Black Mist arrives at a certain point and starts damaging you as well as preventing all healing. The turn count for this is usually pretty reasonable to do unless you are actively stalling and with a few exceptions in the later areas.
On the other hand, not having any healing or support will quickly lead to some of the more grindier fights to wear down your party members. Debuffs and Buffs are also very crucial, as they usually are in these kinds of games, and work just fine on bosses as well (although there is a mechanic in place preventing singular characters to be stunlocked for multiple consecutive turns)

That is to say, the combat has a lot of depth to master and there is quite a lot of replayability in trying different strategies and character combinations.

 I should mention that although this game quite heavily focuses on narrative and lore, the in-game story isn't actually finished yet, although what is there is already pretty promising. Devs are pretty regularly updating the game with balance patches as well as new content, both gameplay and story-wise, so I'm confident that this is not a game that will rot away in Early Access Hell and I honestly always look forward what they will bring next.

Overall, this game definitely stands out for me in the Roguelike crowd due to its unique setting, clean audiovisual presention and deep, engaging combat. Definitely try it out if you are into the likes of Darkest Dungeon, Slay the Spire etc.

Every character is unique and interesting, and this game has some of the most compelling healing characters/mechanics that I've seen in general. Updates have done a great job at giving players more agency and control over the deck and events. They've added card upgrades, including synergy upgrades unique to the characters in your party. While there isn't too much diversity in encounters yet, the combat is engaging and strategic even early on (beyond the first floor). As usual for this genre, there are relics (teamwide passives), equipment (2 per character), skills (cards), and card upgrades that can completely change your run. Unlocks are limited to new characters, relics, equipment, and skills—no permanent stat increases. The bits of story are pretty decent so far.

Lucy, the main character, does not actively fight and instead provides "Draw" cards and special abilities for your deck. There are general Draw cards like "draw 1, draw 1 for the next 2 turns", character-specific Draw cards like "draw 2, add Illusion Sword to them", and powers like "replay all the cards played from your hand last turn". It's a unique spin that makes her feel like a vital support for the team.

This game has a unique "healing gauge" (green HP) mechanic where damage reduces your healing gauge, effectively "potential HP". Taking another hit resets the healing gauge from your reduced HP. Healing has full effect on healing gauge and 1/3 effect otherwise (unless the skill has Overheal). Chain heals bounce to other characters but can't heal past the healing gauge. Upon hitting 0 HP or lower, characters enter "Death's Door" and die on the next instance of damage, giving you time to heal/shield them or kill the enemies first. Clearing encounters fully recovers your healing gauge so you have to strike a balance between sustain and rushing enemies down. There's also a Dark Fog mechanic to prevent stalling but it shouldn't matter too much unless you lack damage or are specifically playing around it with relics.

For new players, I suggest bringing at least one healer and more than one source of primary damage. You don't really need to level your characters past 2-3 and should instead increase your max mana and draw skills. Use skill books, generic skills, and events to round out your skills instead. Try to have a debuff clearing skill (consider making it Fixed), especially for Pain debuffs since those can grow out of control. Be sure to use your consumables as they can make or break runs in this game.

The game does well to make each run feel different by not withholding characters from you, but also the devs not withholding their creative ability when designing each character and boss. Each one plays (so far at least) extremely uniquely, and its hard to categorise each character into a very simple "tank, healer and DPS" nomenclature , and that's not even considering the items and relics which'll adjust how well you perform a certain build or task.
As for the bosses, there is some very interesting mechanics, such as juggling a debuff to avoid nuking your team, or being given a limited card every turn (which'll cure one character of a dangerous debuff that the boss applies). The enemy and boss designs are brilliant, especially in the second area of the game - additionally, the music and atmosphere is as good, the music is well blended into the atmosphere of the zone and its a delight to do enemy encounters for all the aforementioned reasons in this review. 

My only complaints is that of some, no doubt, early access jank and problems.

Firstly is how information is displayed on cards and abilities, sometimes it feels overwhelming starting off as to what a card does and when. You could probably make the current card text alot more concise and clear to make the new player experience alot better, though you tend to figure out most of it when you play through it.
Secondly, is the impact of relics and scrolls (I could be wrong about this, depending on the devs vision / roadmap), I feel like teleport and swiftness scrolls serve no function at the moment, and some relics are somewhat superficial as far as their effect goes. If the devs are aiming for a proper roguelike experience (again, they might not be) then it might be worth adding some more game changing relics rather than just stat or percentage increases. 

This also stretches to abilities in some cases, many abilities are quite narrow and the range of character builds are limited, however this impact is offset by the range of characters available and who are to come, and its not really a problem to me because of the range of playable characters. I certainly wouldn't expect multiple completely different build ideas for each character, but having some aspect of control would be cool, e.g. Stronger individual shields for Ironheart, or focus upon party wide shields, or focus on his damage side. Those are my only 2 complaints as of now, aside from that though, I am hugely surprised that such a gem has been hiding from my sight until now, and the seemingly regular updates for this game give me good impressions regarding the developers commitment and I hope their talents get noticed from hereon. This is because the foundation and core systems of the game are well designed and interesting so its just a case of expanding on the possibilities provided by the systems.

Of course, Chrono Ark has its issues. Instead of going over the positives like every other recommended review, let's go over the main issues you'll face. And let's make a "compliment sandwich" out of it.

[h1] The Top Bun [/h1]

[h1] The Meat [/h1]
Chrono Ark suffers from a few things, namely off the top of my head:
1. The game isn't locally English
2. The difficulty varies wildly per run (with an exception)
3. The story is weird

[b] The game isn't locally English. [/b]
I'll give credit where it's due, the localization isn't the worst I've seen. I can follow the dialogue, see what characters intend with their words, and interpret their tone in conversation. I can see the mechanics that the developer lays out and their importance. The one thing that becomes an issue is the complexity of Chrono Ark.
The boss battles are great fun, but later on you'll start facing bosses where you'll be reading a paragraph ""passive"" on what the boss does and their mechanics, all dragged through a language barrier. It's unfortunate, because the second you figure out what the boss does it actually makes some of the most fun boss fights I've had in a deckbuilder.
Sadly, some of the card descriptions suffer from the language barrier too. Case in point, the Chainsaw lady that you start with ended up being really fun to play, one of my favorites to pick. After my first run with her, I dropped her for about 9-10 hours of playtime because I had no idea what any of her cards did. I opted for simpler party members like baseball waifu and her knight in shining armor until I had a better grasp on the mechanics. It isn't IMPOSSIBLE to interpret the text, but there's still some work to go overall.

[b] The difficulty varies wildly per run (with an exception) [/b]
It takes is a single look at the screenshots tab of Slay the Spire to find someone who has created a build that allows them to endlessly draw a single 0-cost card from their deck. It makes the game look easy (though I assure you it's not.)
Chrono Ark doesn't have many of these (to my knowledge) to exploit thankfully, but it's still challenging regardless. Difficulty will vary depending on the party you take; 4 healers will act differently from 4 DPS. The part of this that isn't so accountable is the massive change in difficulty from boss-to-boss. Each level on Chrono Ark has a boss that generates, and while there aren't such massive discrepancies for early levels it becomes blatant on the second-to-last level.
Spoilers ahead for two notable examples:
[spoiler]On the second-to-last level, you need to defeat a boss called "Reaper." He's a tough dude, took me about 4 tries and 18 runs to defeat him the first time. He was a great, massive challenge, but defeating him unlocked the other two bosses of that level. Comparatively, these two bosses are both easier, but the "Sacred Karaela" boss is too much easier. I managed to take her on with 2/4 party members, something that I couldn't think to manage for the other two bosses.
On the final level, the difficulty spikes massively for the final boss. The level itself is fair enough, and after learning what the enemies do it feels way less intimidating, but the final boss doesn't match that. He has ~700 health and a small chunk of armor (25%). I've faced him 3 times, only actually beating him the first time around. He's tough, but unfairly so. There's a move where you can only target him due to a "taunt," but if you don't take care of three other "pillar" enemies, your deck will start filling up with cards that deal 40% true damage to a character upon play or discard. 
This kinda sucks, because it means the fight's over at the halfway point if you:
1. Don't have anyone who can deal with taunt
2. Have someone DIE before they can deal with the taunt
3. Have too tanky of a team with a healer that can't manage to heal 40% of 100 health in a single card
4. Don't have any all-targeting attacks
5. Don't kill the pillars before they start dishing out 40% max health true damage cards
I get the reason for the phase. Building a team around single damage for a single-target boss would mean a cakewalk. I had a Narhan dealing 137 damage crits against single targets that run, but because the thunder cards kept pushing my identify cards out of my hand I couldn't deal with the pillars.
Maybe I'm just a casual (I definitely am) but it seems like a really massive difficulty spike. I'll try to remember to update this part of the review if my feelings change at a later date.
[/spoiler]
For those who skipped the spoiler: the TL;DR is that the discrepancy between the final boss and the previous boss is massive. Said previous boss also has some friends who are much easier compared to him. The final boss is the exception to the varying difficulty, considering his consistent high difficulty.

[b] The story is weird. [/b]
This one is to be expected since the game isn't natively English, but regardless, the story is strange in some areas. When you open the game, you'll get a section of story that seems very inorganic once you actually start playing the game. I'd like to call it a tutorial, but your actual first run teaches you the mechanics better than the starting tutorial. You're brought past some standard stuff that helps you get the concept of the story. In particular, I loved the big "500" that you start your first run with. It's a small detail, but it's very nice.
As you progress in the game, the story sections become more well-written, expressive, and higher quality. They aren't amazing, but they're miles above the inorganic cutscene at the start. For anyone reading this review who is suspect of the idea of a "Party-based" deckbuilder, let me assure you the game owns up to this claim entirely. The party system is not only well done, its enforced. Each character (including you, as Lucy) bring in their own set of skills to the overall deck, and you are encouraged to use skills from everyone in order to use mana efficiently. 
With that all said, let me get some assorted questions many people might have cleared:
"Is the soundtrack good?" Yes, very. Like this is one of those soundtracks you will listen to outside the game its that good.
"Is it broken by infinites like a lot of card games?" Shockingly no, its frankly almost impossible to go infinite at least in any consistent manner as the cost of cards from a given character escalate over time in the same turn as part of the party system.

If you are familiar with deck-builders you wont have any trouble but if you are new then it might take some testing/analysis of the wording to precisely determine the exact effect. This game really impressed me. The fight mechanics are varied; the characters all feel unique; the music is great enough that I find myself listening to it for leisure, which is a rarity from a video game OST for me; what I've experience of the story is intriguing; RNG doesn't feel [i]too[/i] demanding for a successful run; there's a pleasant difficulty curve to draw you in while keeping you engaged in the long-run; and I [i]love[/i] the art style and general aesthetic of the game. 

Chrono Ark doesn't play much like your typical deckbuilding roguelite. While synergies are obviously important, you're never going to stumble across the perfect combination of effects that let you cycle your whole deck and OTK every fight. It feels much more like a traditional turn-based RPG in terms of playstyle. 

I've only really got two major complaints. The first is the UI can be clunky at times. When the field gets stacked with enemies, it's not uncommon for their health bars to overlap and hide crucial information about turn order or health exact health point values. I find it frustrating that I can't look through my items and skills in various situations where it'd be helpful to (such as when drafting a new skill). 

The biggest problem for me is language-based. This game is in [i]desperate[/i] need of some form of problem-solving card text. Anyone with a background in physical card game can tell you how important it is to have consistent wording on your effects. To compound this issue, it's clear the devs are not native English-speakers, which can lead to some additional clunkiness to the wording of effects.

This problem permeates into every element of the game. Card effects, [b]especially[/b] those of debuffs, are worded incredibly inconsistently. Different skills will shift wildly in wording, to the point where it's not even consistent in terms of perspective (that is, first-, second-, and third-person are all used on at least one card). While I have high praise for the variety in fight mechanics, it often took me various tries before I could actually parse the language on some of their gimmicks. Even core character mechanics aren't free from this. It's near-impossible to figure out if one of Azar's skills referencing his [i]Hallowed Sword[/i] mechanic are referring to the [i]buff[/i] Hallowed Sword or the [i]skill[/i] Hallowed Sword as they both have the same name.

The game comes packaged with a VN-style prequel story, so if you're looking for a more plot-focused experienced there's something for you to sink your teeth into. I worry that the aforementioned language difficulties would cut into the experience a lot, but my understanding is that as of writing (ver. 1.63) it's currently incomplete so I haven't personally delved into it just yet.

Ultimately, the problems in how the game presents information to you are relatively minor. It can be frustrating but experience will eventually let you plow through it, anyways. The game itself is a blast and I can't recommend it enough. I'm excited to see further development for it.

You might see a Roguelite deckbuilder and expect something like Slay the Spire, but this doesn't feel similar at all. If you've played Steamworld Quest, this also combines deckbuilding with traditional JRPG combat, but aside from having a party with characters' own stats and cards which get shuffled into a communal deck, it has little in common with Quest. Considering the seemingly unknown status of the game, there are surprisingly a ton of unique mechanics this game uses very well, and it's extremely fun.

Each character has a (usually game-changing for the entire party) passive and a relatively tiny set of skills (cards) which interplay with other characters in ways that provide a surprising variety of strategies. That and the seriously cool cardplay and battle system make this quite a special game: I'm tempted to describe every aspect of the combat, as there are so many unique mechanics here which work together great. The turn order system in particular felt confusing and a bit unfair at first, but is actually really neat and ties into healing in a very clever way; basically, healing is most effective if a character isn't attacked twice in a row, like the recoverable bar in certain fighting games. This means you can manipulate turn order so as to get healing turns in between enemies' activations.

It's a good thing the combat is so special, because there isn't a lot of variety compared with other popular roguelites. There are Relics and character equipment, but the effects seem to be tame stat boosts which don't fundamentally change anything, at least not individually. That's a bit boring, but it's OK because there are a lot of characters and character combos to try, and the combat system is probably best when there isn't the possibility of having untold number of synergies turning you crazy OP like in Slay the Spire and such inspired games.

Some aspects still need development, such as how the ability to save and quit only comes after bosses, around every twenty minutes, and AFAIK you will lose all your progress if you quit or have a computer issue any other time. That's unacceptable for a complete game, but fine for (hopefully) now. In addition, I'd like to see more of the risk-reward options which liven up the early-game of modern roguelites. There's optimization to be had in the way you use the items you find, but as long as you manage to defeat a zone's boss (which to be fair is consistently fun, as they have really clever gimmicks), there aren't many advantages to eke out through clever play. Battles before the first major boss, in particular, feel redundant.

The result is a one-of-a-kind roguelite that manages to feel more like highly tactical JRPG combat, rather than the standard (and also great!) deckbuilder. If that sounds cool, you should try it.

70518591.review:
Learny but rewarding deck-builder with a banger soundtrack. If you're on the fence about this one, here are the mechanics that have made the game stick out to me:

1) Smart card system:
You don't discard at the end of each turn. To balance this, your base card draw is very low, encouraging you to save up cards for the right moment rather than play everything at once. On top of this, up to 4 cards can be designated as available anytime (with a one turn cooldown). This both helps to thin the deck and make play more consistent - a great mechanic. Getting cards with card draw is also consistent - there is a special "shop" specifically for this.

2) Fair mana system:
Max mana can be increased at any time, infinitely (for a price). However, mana cost for cards increases with card use. So far, I haven't found any way to break this game with runaway mana/draw, and I have to respect that, because it pops up often in deck-builders.

3) Weirdness:
Enemies do weird things. Your cards do weird things. Bosses do even weirder things. Most encounters are very unique and demand careful play, even basic ones after the first zone. It really keeps the game from getting old.

4) Health management:
Hard to describe how much I like how the game handles character health. There is a death's door mechanic, but negative health is also a thing. If you don't heal a character that has been hit, they will loose "healable" health next time they are hit, and afterwards it is difficult to get them back to full hp. But heals are also insanely strong if you invest in your healer. This leads to a constant "full health --> near death --> full health --> near death" loop that is much more interesting and challenging than relying on tanking. You always need to reserve some cards/mana for heals or else.

Could add more, but half the fun of the game is figuring stuff out yourself and getting jump-scared by not understanding the bad translation on a debuff and getting wiped from full hp. (its a lot better than it used to be, but be prepared.)

I'd say current content is worth 60-ish hours to fully enjoy, more if you want to win with all characters or challenge yourself not to use some of them. So far there are only 3 difficulties, but do not underestimate hard mode. Updates are pretty frequent.

Chrono Ark is a turn-based, party-based, roguelike card RPG. In addition to being a mouthful of a genre, it's got a lot of really cool and unique mechanics.  You form a party of 4 characters, starting with 2 of your choice, and then drafting 2 more over the course of the game.  Each character's (known as an Investigator) skills get shuffled up in a single deck to draw your hand out of. 

As you're playing cards, enemies have a turn counter that ticks down, and they'll take their actions when they hit 0, so you'll want to consider that with when and what you play.  Your characters will also become overloaded as they play more cards in a single turn, causing their cards to become more expensive.

Health is also pretty unusual.  When a character takes damage, their health becomes a green “healing gauge”, which can be refilled with healing as normal, but if they get hit again, that green bar will become black, and the new life they lost will become the healing gauge instead. Black health is much more difficult to recover, requiring 3 times the normal healing to recover.  There's also a Death's Door system.  A character won't die from being below 0 life until they take one more hit.  If you can get them back above 0, they'll be fine for another hit.  All green health is also healed at the end of every fight, so if you can kill enemies quickly, you can sometimes finish fights without taking much damage at all.

There are something like 20 characters in the game, divided between Defender, Support, and Attacker archetypes, and they all have very unique mechanics.  My favorite is a support named Sizz who has a doll named Eve that will move between allies as you cast ally-targeted skills and follow up any attacks they make.  A few others include Azar, an attacker that can create free illusion sword cards to poke at enemies, or Miss Chain, a defender with a flaming chainsaw whose cards get extra effects if she's already played another card in the last 2 turns.

The game's still in early access, but should be coming out in the next few months.  Most of what's left is story content.  The story has been engaging in an edgy anime timeloop story kind of way, so I'm excited to see where it goes in the end.

[i]Chrono Ark[/i] is a roguelite strategy game with card-based battles. There are still things that are being actively developed and the game is in Early Access. You may encounter some bugs if you play at this time.

There is a small tutorial, though I do hope that this will get updated to be better. When you play through it once, you cannot see it again. And while some basics are explained, a lot are left to the player to learn through trial and error.

There are 3 difficulty levels, Casual, Normal, and Hard. Casual mode shows up after you lose once or twice on Normal difficulty. You cannot unlock new characters in the Casual mode.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The Ark was constructed a long time ago to try to save the world from catastrophe, but its creators disappeared. The world is slowly deteriorating and the legend around the Ark is that the Clock Tower within the Ark can restore the world to a time of the past, essentially reverting back to better and happier times. Nobody know the truth behind this claim but the protagonist, Lucy, seems to be connected to the original creators of the Ark. She will try to save the world, with the help of the characters who will fight with her to achieve their mutual goal.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You play as Lucy, who will choose two characters/friends to fight by her side at the beginning of the run. Lucy does not fight herself, but offers abilities that can come in useful during the fights.

Walking around the world map on each level, Lucy will encounter different areas of interest, such as shops, chests, loot, enemies, and bosses. You will be able to move to the next level once you defeat the boss for that area. In between levels, you may have the option of recruiting more characters for your party to make the game more dynamic as you move along.

The battles are turn-based and you use the few skills/cards that you have for each individual character to defeat the enemies. The fighting system can be a bit difficult to get used to because there are a few different variables to pay attention to. For example, the enemies have a count-down that allows them to perform an action during your turn, and this counts down each time you perform an action.

Winning battles means that you will earn loot in the forms of gold, items, soulstones, and credits. Soulstones can be used to level up your characters and also to upgrade Lucy's skills. Everything is used in the same run, except for credits, which are used in the meta-game to give you a permanent progression unlock. This is done in between runs. You will need many runs to unlock everything.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics are very good. The designs in the overworld all looks very cute, whereas in the battles, you can see the usual signs of danger.

[h1]Music[/h1]
The music can be quite intense at times, it seems appropriate.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
You can play the entire game with the mouse, this mouse-based movement was introduced by a recent update. This is nice because there are some people who don't like to use a keyboard. You can move around using a keyboard, this is sometimes easier.

[h1]Gameplay Video[/h1]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dDU-qB8W1iA

[h1]Pricing[/h1]
The game has a reasonable price, it is 13.99 Euro/16.99 USD at the base asking price right now in Early Access. It has enough content to keep you entertained for a while.
It likely will increase as the game develops more.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
It was a bit overwhelming at first because of the many things that I needed to learn, especially because the tutorial is not that informative. Once I became accustomed to the game system and mechanics, I really enjoyed my time so far. The game is really hard on normal mode, and I still cannot beat level 3 regular monsters when I get there.

I do hope that the game will be better balanced at full release.

Overall score: 7/10

I'd have to say, I'm pretty impressed with this game. I honestly was hooked from the start, but waited to write this review until I had reached my personal goal of clearing normal difficulty of the available content at of EA version 1.1g (ending with the [spoiler] Reaper boss [/spoiler]) so I could have the proper perspective on the game. 

Positives:
[list]
[*]As of this review, there are 12 heroes (with 20 planned it seems) and they all (with my personal exception of one [spoiler] the Phoenix, which is just a bit "gimmicky" for my taste) [/spoiler] feel great. Every hero has a purpose, multiple ways to build them, unique / creative concepts / mechanics, and just feels [i]fun[/i] to try out each one as you unlock them and try new combos and strategies.

[*]A different approach to leveling up. In the course of a run (this is a rogue-lite, after all) you'll get these "Soul Stone" items which you use to level up not only your heroes, but your main person (Lucy) as well. This gives you a flexibility to choose how your party progresses in strength, and gives you, the player, more control over your strategy.

[*]You get your main person (Lucy) who works alongside your party of (up to) 4 heroes, fulfilling a certain kinda of support; not only in cards which specialize in drawing cards, but also a couple of other ways, like enhancing a hero's card for that battle, and other potent effects.

[*]As I mentioned in my first point, the teambuilding in this game feels great. I've played a lot of other deckbuilders, and Slay the Spire is great of course, but it's cool to see a team-based deckbuilder roguelite adventure game carve out its own niche in an ever-growing market where it seems like everyone is making their own deckbuilder game.

[*]Meta progression unlocks cool stuff for your future runs, similar to other roguelites. Using these "credits" which you get from defeating bosses n such during a run, you can unlock not only more equipment & relics, but also more common skills (skills which can be used by any hero) for your heroes to learn (and more skills for Lucy to learn). These unlocks, of course, help you become stronger for subsequent runs. Thankfully, the game is very much skill based, so while these unlocks help, player skill is [i]really[/i] what leads to success on a run, not how much you've unlocked.

[*]A different approach to battles. In most deckbuilders, it goes "my turn -- enemy's turn". In this game, it uses a system where enemies go after X number of actions (as indicated next to an enemy) which you do, meaning the enemies can "interrupt you during your turn". There are some ways around this, but the point is that you have to carefully plan out your turns around this mechanic and pay attention not only to your mana, but to what the enemies are doing as well.

[*]Similar to Darkest Dungeon, this game uses the "On Death's Door" mechanic for dying, meaning that the game will give you a chance to heal a hero before they die (and thus taking them off Death's Door). I like this mechanic's flexibility, as it allows you to react to bad situations most of the time instead of "lol you're suddenly dead" (though sudden fatalities can still happen, of course).
[/list]
I could go on about a few things, but I'll go over some "Negatives", which overall aren't that bad in my opinion, but I'll mention a few things so you can have a better picture:
[list]
[*]The developer is Korean, meaning that the English translation can be "a little rough" at times. While this may be the case, I've never really had any "issues" with being able to read things, and quite recently before writing this review, the developer had done another localization sweep and significantly improved the English from its former state. Essentially, yes, it's a translation, but the developer has shown that they care about making sure it's readable / playable for English players as well.

[*]There are a few wonky / odd mechanics and explanations in the game. Admittedly, it would be a little difficult to describe some of these oddities if you weren't already familiar with the game, but suffice to say there is a little bit of learning curve with some of the heroes / skills / items / consumables / bosses / etc because some thing don't explain themselves very well or don't act in the way you would've "expected them to". I can quite understand how this might be a little troublesome for some players who might have less amounts of patience per se, but if you're willing to give the game a chance instead of ragequitting when an unexpected or "seemingly unexplained" thing happens and take the time to understand it, your future runs will be fine. Remember: things happen for a reason, and I've had a lot of "Oh I get it now" moments while playing this game.

[*]More of a "mixed" instead of pure negative: As of this review, you get some unlocked rewards for beating the current content with any given hero on normal difficulty (one unlock per hero), but [i]don't[/i] get any rewards for clearing it on hard. I [i]guess or presume[/i] that this might change in the future, but mentioning it here so people are aware.

[*]During boss encounters, you don't win until you defeat [i]all enemies on the screen[/i]. This means you have to kill summoned minions even if you kill the boss first. Some might consider this "generally annoying" (in terms of taking more time), and others might even get a little upset when they "barely killed the boss but then got killed by the leftover minion so the victory doesn't count and it's actually a defeat" (that's happened to me before haha). So, it's not the end of the world to me, and I can understand this mechanic existing, but some might not be that keen on it.
[/list]
I think I'll cut things there for now.

So, if I had to describe what this game "feels like" to me, I'd say it's like someone combined elements of Slay the Spire, Darkest Dungeon, and a Chinese / Korean Dungeon Crawler RPG, blended it up, and made it their own. I can tell from just how creative the various heroes and mechanics are that this developer cares about not only making games, but playing them. This is a game which was "made by a gamer, for gamers".

Chrono Ark is definitely a hidden gem among others roguelike games on PC, despite being made by a small dev team, the game got a pretty interesting world setup and gameplay/battle mechanics.

Important note: since the game is an Early Access, you can expect a lot of errors in the english translation, but it's bearable. Just don't focus on them too much. 

[h1] The Story[/h1]
Apparently, it was discovered that the modern humanity will soon encounter a devastating apocalypse, known as "Grand Catastrophe". It seems that was impossible to prevent and so most countries started thinking about survival. 

Some decided to do a cryogenic sleep in isolated shelters, with a hope that many years later this disaster will disappear, some decided to do other things and among those projects was "The Ark", an artificial created land/city, which will provide humanity with all needs.

The main character, Lucy, awakened in a middle of the Twisted Land with no memories and encounter people from the Ark. Turns out that the creators of Ark disappeared with a trace and now, even thought it's safe at the moment, the future of Ark looks grim. Thus they formed an investigation squad to sent outside, for gathering information and searching for fragments of the mysterious clock tower, which among some theories, could turn back the time before "the Grand Catastrophe" happened.

During your runs, you will find stuff like tapes, photos and videos, which will explain more about the story. Overall, it's pretty interesting and i hope it will stay that way.
Sadly, in the current EA 1.04 there's not much story content.

[h1] The Gameplay[/h1]
Before you start your adventure, the game will ask you to form a party.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1947608514 
Each character in the game feels really unique, so you can create some interesting party setups. However, at the start you can only choose 2 character for your party.

In order to unlock new possible party members, you need to fulfill a specific conditions, either completing X stage or doing some crazy objective. You can scroll over and read the requirements. 

[b]Small advice[/b]: it is NOT recommended to use two healers setup, as the game HEAVILY punish defensive/passive setups. Most normal battles got a hard requirement of MAX turns available and if you exceed that number, you will receive a strong HP Damage-over-time and Healing debuffs. 

Your best bet is 1 DPS + 2 Tanks + Healer or 2 DPS + Tank + Healer.
My personal favorite is 1 DPS + 1 HybridDPS Tank + Full Support Tank (Ironheart) + Healer.
It's hard to advice a specific character, because they all are usable and you need to build them in a manner that you want to play. 

There's not much to say about dungeon exploration, you move your character in isometric-like style, while collecting stuff on the ground and engaging in battles.
There's a few events that you need to pay attention to:
1) Trader - this guy here will sell random equipments, skillbooks and scrolls. Important: ALWAYS BUY all available "KEY" first, other than that, pay attention to the skillboks, sometimes there great abilities like "Double Attack", "Rash" and some others.

2) Library - this thing can do one equipment item enchant FOR FREE. However, you should have at least 200/400 Gold with you for a reroll in-case you get a negative (debuff) effect.

3) Smithery - this one is important in case you get too much artifacts and want to turn useless ones into a new random one higher tier or transform it into another random artifact within same tier.
Tiers are as follows -> White -> Green -> Blue -> Purple -> Orange.
For Purple don't mistake Equipment and Relic items, Purple relic items are actually placed in a specific box, which you can find in your camp, when you rest between stages.

4) Altar of Greed - the one building that will ask you for food and in exchange will give you random items. So far here's the list of items that i managed to find there:
- 1 Gold
- 400 Gold
- Legendary (Orange) tier skills for Lucy, this one is a Jackpot, honestly.
- Potions 
This building is always a risky move, so be aware.

5) Water Oasis, that will make you forget one skill and choose another. Recommended to use on Lucy to get a better Draw skill. Not sure if erased skill is random or not, so keep that in mind.

6) Mysterious Pot - throw 2 useless items in there and get a new random one. Potions with negative effects are your best candidates

[b]Now, let's move to the most interesting part of the game.	[/b]
Battles in the game is like a TCG with dungeon crawler RNG elements. All skill/cards and enemies animations are flashy and well done. The gameplay itself is pretty dynamic and fast too.

Each turn you will draw random cards from your deck, that you can use. Even though Lucy don't fight at front line, her skills will help you greatly to get more available cards in your hand.

When you receive damage, you will notice a green HP bar - this is one of the most important mechanics in the game. While the bar is green you need to heal that character HP, if he will receive another hit, he will lose a big portion of that green bar.
While it is still possible to heal characters even if they lost the green bar, the effect of that healing will be heavily diminished (it will be like 60% or more weaker, compared to base Heal value).
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1947509660 
There's a lof of possible characters/card combination and most of them you should be able to understand with common sense & experience (after you play the game for a few hours).
Another very important battle note is "Fixed skills". 

"Fixed" skill will become available each turn, however, for most skills you can only use 1 fixed skill each turn, the others will turn gray.
The cost of fixed skill permanently raise up by one point and you will no be able to draw it from deck via normal means.
Also, some skills can't be fixed and the only way to use them is to draw via normal means.

The boss fights in this game can be really tricky, pay close attention to what the boss do and all various buffs on them and pop-ups. I will speak only about the current available last boss in the game, because that guy is a walking disaster. Other bosses you should defeat without much problems, just pay attention.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1947509814  
Okay, the most annoying boss fight in the game, that can make you rage - The Reaper. 
Note: make sure you at least at Normal difficulty, otherwise you will not be able to unlock new character.

The Reaper got a pretty dangerous mechanic that will result in a party wipe if you're unlucky or didn't pay attention.

Each time when you press "End Turn" the boss will inflicts one target with Death Sentence debuff. However, there's a clear pattern when he choose his target -> he attacks the target which skill is curently is on the top of your hand. 

This means every turn you need to have a different character skill on top of your hand or it's pretty much a gameover. While it's possible to survive ONE Death Sentence, the second is a 100% finish.

Death Sentence = 20 True Damage (ignores everything) to your entire party. Death Sentence activates each time when he hit the target already affected by this debuff, that's why you need to take this debuff with different character each time.

Good luck and let the RNG be with you!

[h1] The Final Verdict[/h1]
8.5/10
The game is really good, you can feel the passion and talent from the devs, even when it lacks content and there's a lot of typos too. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)
The battle system and overall game balance are well thought too.
